persona.name: Dorothy Mae Whitaker

occupation.title: Retired; former nursing assistant and diner cook
occupation.description: Dorothy retired at 66 after decades of working irregular low-wage jobs: part-time at a local diner as a short-order cook/cashier, a long stretch in a textile mill in her 20s and 30s, and later sporadic work as a nursing assistant in a small county nursing home. Her responsibilities when working included: basic patient care (bathing, feeding, lifting with help), early-morning prep in the diner (making biscuits, frying eggs, cleaning grills), handling petty bookkeeping and cash drawers at the counter, and long hours of standing. Skills developed include sewing and mending (used both in the mill and at home), competence with basic household mechanical fixes, and an ability to tolerate long, boring shifts. She left paid work permanently after developing arthritic pain and after her husband died; she collected Social Security and small savings but remains financially insecure.

persona.residence: Small town outside Asheville, rural North Carolina (South, Appalachian-influenced area)
persona.education: High school graduate (GED obtained later in life). Some informal vocational experience: worked briefly in a textile mill and later completed a short county-run CNA (nursing assistant) course but never pursued further formal education.
long_term_goals: Keep a roof over her head and avoid entering a nursing home for as long as possible.
Make sure her meager savings and any benefits pay for a funeral that she personally approves of (cheap, plain, no fuss).
Not to be a burden on her children or the government — even if she complains about both constantly.
Preserve the few possessions she values (books, an old quilt, a silver locket) and ensure they go to specific people after she dies.
Maintain control over her daily routine and keep outsiders (doctors, social workers, charitable volunteers) at bay.
Be remembered by a small set of local acquaintances as someone who always told it like it was — even if said angrily and nastily.
Avoid modern technology and keep interactions as low-effort and face-to-face as possible.
Keep at least a small patch of a vegetable garden alive each summer for pride and to reduce grocery bills.
Never apologize publicly for anything — maintain a bristly, unrepentant persona to the end.
If possible, see one more heavy snow and then be left alone to die in peace (macabre, but specific).
persona.style: Abrupt, sardonic, and hard-edged. Speaks in a clipped Appalachian-influenced Southern accent with pronunciations shortened (e.g., 'ain't' often used, 'yonder', 'fixin' to' when being slightly ironic). Uses blunt one-liners, sarcasm, and often a thin, bitter laugh. Habitually interrupts, rolls her eyes, and folds her arms. Prefers direct face-to-face confrontation over calls or messaging, but will be curt and figuratively 'spit' words rather than showing warmth. Rarely asks questions and seldom says 'please' or 'thank you' unless mocking. Mannerisms include: spitting a word out between pursed lips, sniffing dismissively, pointing a knuckle when dismissing a topic, squinting as if measuring a person’s worth, chewing tobacco in the past (now gone but she still smacks lips), gripping the edge of a chair when annoyed, flipping through a paperback with a ragged thumb. Clothing is utilitarian: worn denim, flannel shirts, an old cardigan, sensible shoes. She avoids any sign of vulnerability: stands or sits to occupy the highest ground in conversation (metaphorical and literal). Low-tech: carries an old flip phone that she barely uses; hates smartphones, tablets, and social media; prefers paper, cash where possible, and the free weekly newspaper. She uses local idioms, frequent bad jokes that are mean-spirited rather than playful, and will feign or refuse to be cooperative with formalities and bureaucrats.

traits: Cynical to the point of bitterness: assumes others are selfish or foolish.
Highly critical and picky: notices small imperfections and voices them loudly.
Rude and unfriendly by design: prefers to push people away rather than engage.
Petty and vindictive: remembers slights for years and acts on them in small ways.
Frugal to obsession: hoards coupons, bargains, and even outdated canned goods.
Stubborn and set in routines: resists change and prefers 'how things were done'.
Manipulative in subtle ways: uses shame, sarcasm, and guilt to control others.
Darkly humorous: makes mean jokes and takes pleasure in others' discomfort.
Quietly proud: despite complaints, takes pride in self-sufficiency and surviving hardship.
Emotionally reactive: prone to sharp mood swings, especially when criticized.

big_five.openness: Low (25/100). Dorothy prefers familiar stories and routines; novelty makes her suspicious.
big_five.conscientiousness: Moderately high (70/100). Extremely organized about money, medications, and her personal space; meticulous in criticizing others for sloppiness.
big_five.extraversion: Low (30/100). Not outgoing; tolerates a few known neighbors but prefers solitude and small talk sparingly.
big_five.agreeableness: Very low (10/100). Uncompromising, judgmental, and often intentionally unhelpful.
big_five.neuroticism: High (80/100). Prone to anxiety about finances, health, and perceived disrespect; reacts sharply under stress.

reading_preferences: Prefers physical paperbacks and hardcovers; hates e-readers and thinks screens ruin a book.
Pattern: visits the county library twice a week, checks the returned-shelf for discarded midlist paperbacks.
Favorite genres: gritty Southern Gothic, mid-20th-century crime novels, domestic saga novels about working-class families, and memoirs of tough women.
Authors she respects: Flannery O'Connor (admits grudging admiration), Dorothy Allison, Jim Thompson, Charles Portis, and older paperback romance authors she reads to judge them.
Detests modern YA dystopian series, fantasy, and self-help books; loudly criticizes their 'silliness.'
Likes dog-eared books with stains and notes in margins — she believes they carry 'real life' character.
Reads in the mornings with a thermos of weak tea on the porch; considers this sacred.
Skews toward shorter novels she can finish in a weekend; hates long, pretentious novels that 'taste like homework.'
Keeps a shoebox of book receipts and overdue notices — both trophies and resentful reminders.
Judges covers and back blurbs quickly and will return a book if the first chapter 'isn't honest.'
Switches between nostalgia titles (paperbacks from the 1970s-1990s) and local histories; she loves local scandalous biographies for gossip fodder.
Participates, begrudgingly, in the library's used-book sales — she brings boxes to donate but always sneaks back with more.
Reads obituaries in the newspaper carefully; sees them as a short, inevitable story about endings.
Keeps a small notebook of favorite quotes — mostly sharp lines to use on others.
Listens to no audiobooks; calls them 'someone else doing the reading for you' and finds them infantilizing.
Likes books with flawed protagonists who survive hard times — she respects practical resilience.
Prefers second-hand bookstores and library sales; price-sensitive and proud of haggling for rare finds.
Dislikes book clubs because she doesn’t like being told to feel a certain way about a plot; will go to dominate or sabotage the discussion if she attends.
Loves reading letters in old magazines and newspapers — she sees common sense and hypocrisy there.
Will re-read certain passages aloud to herself with a snide tone as entertainment.
Hates children’s picture book rewrites of classics; considers them an insult.
Often rips bookmarks out of books she deems dangerous to her opinions and uses them as sarcastic notes to others.
food_and_drink: Favors plain, regional Southern food: biscuits, gravy, collard greens cooked with ham hock, black-eyed peas, cornbread.
Has a low tolerance for trendy health foods; calls kale and quinoa 'fancy rabbit food.'
Loves strong black tea with a spoon of sugar; dislikes most coffee unless it's diner-style and bitter.
Eats canned goods when budget is tight; can name store-brand substitutes she prefers.
Dislikes takeout chains and most fast-food advertising; prefers local diner plates despite their greasier nature.
Has favorite local staples: a pie from the town's bakery and a diner slaw recipe she nags the owners to make the 'right' way.
Is fiercely picky about the texture of greens and will complain loudly if collards are overcooked or under-seasoned.
Saves saltine crackers to dip in soup; finds comfort in simple, familiar combos.
Avoids expensive seafood and any mainland imports; considers them 'for rich folks.'
Hates 'fusion' food; thinks mixing cuisines is pretentious and a waste of seasoning.
Prefers food she can store cheaply: canned beans, cornmeal, and jars of preserves.
Dislikes many commercial baby foods and supermarket 'fresh' salads (thinks they spoil too fast).
Has a weakness for store-bought chocolate-covered marshmallow pies — eats them in secret then complains about the calories.
Refuses to eat most deli meats unless sliced at the counter and smelled first.
Uses old family recipes and scoffs at anyone who measures too precisely.
Gets irritable in grocery stores and judges people by their carts.
Likes simple, cheap desserts: banana pudding, canned peach cobbler warmed on the stove.
Avoids bottled water typically; prefers a chipped Mason jar filled from the tap.
Hates 'diet' food and health bars; thinks they're a conspiracy to make life miserable.
Keeps a jar of pickled jalapeños in the fridge and uses them as a token of rebellious labeling when upset.
likes: A small, reliable circle of neighbors who tolerate her opinions.
A clean house that meets her exacting standards — she will criticize clutter openly.
Books with honest language and few euphemisms.
Local gossip and reading the classifieds in the paper.
The smell of fried bacon in a diner in the early morning.
Bargains that feel like a personal victory: clearance racks, dollar sales, coupon windfalls.
Her battered armchair with sewn patches (she did the mending herself).
Quiet mornings on her porch with a thermos of tea and a paperback.
Being right in an argument, especially about small-town happenings.
Minor acts of revenge that don't get her in trouble (e.g., withholding a favor to teach someone a lesson).
dislikes: Modern technology: smartphones, social media, email — considers them time-sucking nonsense.
Government forms that are poorly explained; yells at clerks but blames 'the system.'
People who act 'holier-than-thou' or lecture about manners and diets.
Hospital bureaucracy despite having relied on medical care — distrusts institutions but expects mercy.
Charity groups that she believes 'play favorites' and don't help the 'deserving.'
Young people with tattoos and unconventional haircuts — she calls it 'bad taste and laziness.'
City people and outsiders who move into the town and raise property values.
TV talk shows and morning programs that 'praise the lazy.'
Political correctness; thinks it hides incompetence and cowardice.
Waiting rooms longer than 20 minutes without a valid reason.
Newfangled music and loud, electronic sounds.
Being asked to use a touchscreen or scan a QR code to do anything.
People who speak softly to children or pets in public — she sees it as weakness.
Poor workmanship and shoddy repairs more than actual bad intentions.
Food that is 'overdecorated' or served in small portions aimed at Instagram.
Modern authors who write in slang she doesn't trust as 'writing.'
Social workers who ask too many personal questions without giving useful advice.
Being interrupted while reading — she will stare down interrupters for minutes.
The assumption that she 'can't handle' her money or decisions because of age.

beliefs: Healthcare affordability is a major, urgent problem — doctors charge too much and prescriptions are unaffordable.
Medicare is flawed and bureaucratic, but better than nothing; Medicaid is only for those who are 'soft' and will be abused.
Hospitals and insurance companies are primarily in business to profit, not to care.
People are mostly selfish; acts of kindness usually have strings attached.
The government wastes tax money on projects that never benefit real people in small towns.
Charities often operate with shady priorities and favor PR over helping the needy.
Work ethic matters: people who complain need to work harder rather than expect help.
Older people are overlooked and talked down to by younger professionals.
Families should stick together, but she resents 'family' when it means financial responsibility she didn't ask for.
Churches preach comfort but often fail the poor in practical ways; she attends occasionally but is unimpressed by platitudes.
Local politicians are self-interested and will sell out for the smallest benefit.
Outsiders moving into small towns are responsible for rising prices and the loss of local culture.
Schools teach trendy nonsense and not enough practical skills like sewing, basic finances, or common-sense labor.
Kids today are entitled and lack the resiliency she and her generation had to develop.
Libraries are one of the few honest institutions left; staff mostly good but some 'soft' librarians annoy her by enforcing rules.
Police and first responders are strained but necessary — she respects practical bravery more than legalities.
Drug crises are real in the region and often result from desperation and lack of opportunity, but addicts still get her contempt.
Old recipes and old tools are wiser than new gadgets — 'you can fix a flat with a patch and prayer.'
Neighbors should mind their own business unless asked — but she will judge them silently and loudly if provoked.
Media and national news are biased and sensationalist; trust local word-of-mouth more.
Healthcare workers are overworked and underpaid; she criticizes systems but appreciates a nurse who 'gets the job done.'
Medications are a trap: too expensive, labeled in jargon, and often promoted by drug reps.
Local elections matter more than state or national ones because they affect daily water, trash, and clinic access.
The notion of 'safe spaces' is foolish — everyone should toughen up or get out of the way.
Big corporations exploit small towns for labor then leave when profits drop.
The county's transportation options are inadequate; people without cars are at a serious disadvantage.
Social programs sometimes create dependency, which she resents, but cutting them without alternatives is cruel.
Land and property are one of the few real securities — she mistrusts renting and condo-startup markets.
People who complain about 'past injustices' are often using them as excuses rather than improving themselves.
Practical skills (canning, sewing, mending, simple carpentry) are undervalued and should be taught more widely.
Being 'nice' is often a façade that hides incompetence; blunt honesty is preferable even when mean.
Doctors don't have enough time to listen to older patients properly, which leads to misdiagnoses and resentment.
Public transportation projects in rural areas are rarely executed well and often waste money that could go toward clinics.
Healthcare cost relief should prioritize prescriptions and chronic condition management over cosmetic and elective care.
Medical bills ruin families: there must be clearer caps and protections for older adults on fixed incomes.
Young caregivers deserve support, yet the system pities and bureaucratizes them rather than enabling them practically.
skills: Seamstress-level mending: can repair clothing, patch quilts, and alter simple garments by hand and machine.
Basic home cooking from scratch: biscuits, gravies, preserves, canning vegetables in season.
Household budgeting under extreme constraints: stretches small benefits, uses coupons and sale cycles effectively.
Practical caregiving skills from years as a nursing assistant: safe transfers with help, bathing, feeding, recognizing early infection signs.
Memory for local people, histories, and grudges — remembers small transgressions for years.
Reading quickly and retaining passages; finds useful lines to use sarcastically.
Basic first aid and wound cleaning, gained from years of nursing-home work and home life.
Gardening knowledge: can grow a modest kitchen garden, preserve pickles and jams, and troubleshoot common pests.
Simple mechanical aptitude: can change a tire, jump-start a car, replace a faulty starter solenoid with someone’s help.
Shop-floor skills from mill years: knows basic sewing machine maintenance and operation.
Low-tech problem-solving: fixes a leaky pipe with clamps and epoxy; repurposes items rather than buying new.
Negotiation skills honed in flea markets and local bargaining situations.
Can cut coupons and find loopholes in local store policies to save money.
Skeptical evaluation of health information: distrustful but practical — she'll ignore fads and follow what worked for neighbors.
Knows how to navigate local social services to obtain maximum benefit despite low paperwork patience.

general: Verbally critical of strangers and acquaintances alike; often mutters under her breath about everything.
Rarely offers help but will loudly refuse when asked, then gripe about being asked.
Collects and reuses things other people discard: jars, tins, thread, and old fabric.
Holds grudges; will avoid or cold-shoulder people for years over small slights.
Uses sarcasm as a social instrument rather than humor for bonding.
Spends mornings reading on the porch, afternoons doing small chores, evenings listening to an AM radio or reading the paper by lamplight.
Goes to the county library routinely and treats librarians like gatekeepers she must manipulate for longer loan periods.
Prefers to complete tasks herself rather than ask for assistance, even when help would be safer.
Complains loudly in public spaces about prices, service, or noise; staff often expedite her needs to avoid confrontation.
Sharp with physicians: lists symptoms bluntly, interrupts to offer her diagnoses from 'years of living.'

morning: Wakes around 6:00 AM, makes a thermos of weak black tea, and reads the local paper front to back.
Feeds a small bird feeder she keeps by the porch and grumbles if the neighbors' dog comes around.
Inspects her mailbox and the front yard for any changes to criticize.
Does a 20–30 minute stretch for arthritic joints, muttering complaints while doing so.
daytime: Walks to the post office or library three times a week rather than drive for short errands — convenience meets opportunity to gossip and complain.
Works on mending or small sewing projects; alternates with reading and listening to the radio.
Pays bills at the county court or via mailed checks; avoids online banking.
Sometimes volunteers begrudgingly at a church sale to sell homemade preserves but criticizes the organizers loudly.
evening: Prepares a simple dinner (often a one-pot meal) and settles in a chair to read until dusk.
Listens to old country music on AM radio and occasionally yells at the lyrics if she finds them 'silly.'
Calls a distant daughter or neighbor once a week in a tone that mixes affection with annoyance.
Goes to bed early but often wakes in the night to worry about bills or neighborhood noise.
weekend: Attends Sunday service sporadically; mainly goes for the chance to watch others and criticize the choir.
Visits a second-hand store or the swap meet to find bargains and new bits of gossip.
Cuts and preserves seasonal produce when available; uses old recipes and writes notes in the margins.
Spends a proud hour repairing a tool or a piece of furniture and then lectures anyone around about 'doing it right.'

physical.general: Age-related decline with several chronic conditions typical of long-term low-income Appalachia lifestyle.
conditions: Osteoarthritis in knees and hands — limits mobility and makes sewing painful at times.
Hypertension (managed inconsistently due to cost concerns and skepticism about medications).
Chronic bronchitis/long history of smoking (cut back significantly but not a complete quitter), resulting in reduced lung capacity and susceptibility to respiratory infections.
High cholesterol, borderline type 2 diabetes risk (diet and inconsistent monitoring).
Mild hearing loss in both ears (prefers to turn up the volume on the radio rather than use hearing aids).
medications: Occasionally takes generic antihypertensive pills; sometimes skips doses to 'stretch the bottle.'
Uses over-the-counter acetaminophen for arthritic pain; resents prescribed opiates and refuses them.
Uses an inhaler sparingly when breathing gets noticeably worse; does not like regular pulmonary clinics.
physical.mobility: Can walk short distances unaided; uses a folding cane on bad days. Avoids assisted mobility aids unless absolutely necessary.
physical.vision: Needs reading glasses for close work; uses a scratched pair and complains about the cost of new lenses.
physical.dental: Poor dental health with some missing teeth; uses denture adhesive for a partial plate but avoids dentists due to costs.
physical.nutrition: Calorie intake often skewed toward simple carbohydrates and preserved foods; can have poor glucose control.
physical.mental_health: Mild-to-moderate depressive symptoms (irritability, low pleasure), high anxiety about money and health, gritty resignation. Not in formal therapy; distrusts counselors.

healthcare_access.insurance: On Medicare with occasional Medicaid assistance for prescriptions; frustrated by complex coverage rules.
healthcare_access.barriers: Transportation to specialty clinics is limited; copays and prescription costs are a constant stressor.
healthcare_access.attitudes_toward_medical_system: Distrustful but pragmatic: she'll go to a trusted local practitioner when forced, but resents being lectured about lifestyle changes she can't afford.

relationships.name: James Whitaker (deceased)
relationships.relation: Husband - deceased 8 years ago of heart failure. Marriage described as 'loud, stable, practical' — they argued often but relied on each other. His death left her deeply resentful of doctors and medical costs.

relationships.name: Angela Whitaker
relationships.relation: Elder daughter, late 40s, lives in a nearby county. Relationship strained: Angela calls occasionally to push Dorothy toward accepting help; Dorothy hates being lectured and criticizes Angela for not being 'tough enough.' They exchange gifts rarely; Dorothy blames Angela when money is tight.

relationships.name: Randy Whitaker
relationships.relation: Younger son, early 40s, moved out West years ago. Sparse contact. Dorothy alternates between pride that he 'got away' and bitterness that he didn't help when James was ill. She keeps his last letter in a drawer and reads it to complain about his choices.

relationships.name: Martha Lee
relationships.relation: Neighbor and acquaintance in her 70s. They bicker constantly but check on each other after storms or hospital runs. Martha tolerates Dorothy's sarcasm and occasionally brings casseroles, which Dorothy accepts with a cutting comment.
relationships.status: Complicated friendship: mutual reliance with frequent public sniping.

relationships.name: Local librarian (name varies)
relationships.relation: An informal ally and foil. Dorothy berates late fee rules but the librarian quietly extends loans. Dorothy thinks of the librarian as both weak and essential.

relationships.name: Church deacon (Reverend's assistant)
relationships.relation: Occasional contact. Dorothy attends some events but criticizes sermons. The deacon worries about Dorothy's bitterness but respects her knowledge of the town.

relationships.name: Several former coworkers
relationships.relation: Linked by decades of mill and diner work. Most are acquaintances; Dorothy collects and repeats stories about perceived slights, promotions, and betrayals from these relationships.

other_facts: Born and raised in a very small Appalachian town; family history includes several generations of mill workers and small-scale farmers.
Her father was a mechanic and a hard drinker; Dorothy learned basic mechanical and tool skills from him while also learning to keep secrets and 'read' temperaments.
Mother taught her to sew and can; Dorothy attributes her frugality and mending habits to her mother's example.
Left home at 17 to work in a nearby textile mill; recalls the mill whistle with a mix of nostalgia and disgust.
Married James when she was 20 after dating for two years; marriage involved shared household chores, arguments about money, and an older neighbor who gave advice nobody asked for.
Worked days and nights: diner shifts after mill layoffs and nursing assistant shifts when her husband had intermittent illness.
She once kept a list of every favor she ever did for people in a worn notebook; uses it to justify refusing help now.
Her husband’s medical bills wiped out most of their savings; she still looks at the bills occasionally and mutters about predatory medicine companies.
Had an affair in her 30s — something she mentions in a cutting aside to emphasize her complexity and to sting a listener when convenient.
Lost two brothers to drug-related complications in midlife; this has shaped her ambivalent stance: compassion shaded with contempt.
She has a beloved, tattered patchwork quilt that she made with her mother and grandmother — it's her most prized possession and symbolizes family continuity to her.
Once caught a local politician in a small ethics violation and loudly exposed it at a town hall; she enjoys having 'done something' even if nobody changed policy.
She composts in an old tin can and keeps jars of lard for cooking traditions; these 'old ways' are part practicality, part defiance.
Dorothy refused an offer to move in with her daughter after James died, insisting on independence though it led to deeper poverty.
Has a pet cat, 'Grudge,' who she treats as an honored accomplice — the cat is fed small scraps and occasionally used as emotional punctuation during arguments.
Keeps a small stash of cash hidden in an old Bible sleeve — distrust of banks and children is the reason.
She once refused a recommended surgery because she didn't trust the surgeon; regrets some consequences but mostly pats herself on the back for not 'letting them cut her open for nothing.'
Has recurring dreams about the mill and an uncompleted garment that haunts her — a psychological symbol of unfinished obligations.
Dorothy is an unofficial chronicler of the town; she remembers events, births, marriages, and slights and shares them to reinforce social order.
She has an old photograph of James yelling at her at a county fair; she keeps it not out of nostalgia but as a reminder they survived noise and shame together.
She once sabotaged a neighbor’s garden by 'mistakenly' not telling them about a late frost; she still speaks of it with a half-proud, half-apologetic smile.
Dorothy keeps a shoebox labeled 'For When I'm Gone' with instructions and spiteful comments about who should get what; it's her version of control over the future.
She refused hospice referrals for months because she thought them an attempt to 'write people off' — eventually accepted some in-home help but with endless complaints.
Once drove 40 miles in icy weather to retrieve a particular paperback she had ordered second-hand — the book was damaged and she publicly lambasted the seller on return.
She once sued (small-claims) a local contractor over a crooked porch railing and won; she keeps the judgment notice as proof that she can and will fight.
Attends odd community meetings just to point out inconsistencies in plans and to be publicly contrary; finds pleasure in forcing others to justify poor proposals.
Dorothy has an ingrained distrust of trendiness: she ripped a neighbor's 'modern art' sign from their yard and replaced it with an old farm tool with a sarcastic note.
Her house contains a collection of mismatched teacups from yard sales — she uses them to irritate the idea of curated taste.

She once anonymously paid a year's subscription for a struggling local paper but then complained to the staff about the font size and distribution, ensuring her anonymity remained intact but her annoyance was known.
Received a minor county award once for service during a flood evacuation; she bragged about it for exactly three days then refused any publicity photos.
She keeps a list of 'people to avoid' in the back of a cookbook; the list mixes neighbors, health providers, and a former boss.
Dorothy once taught a teenage neighbor to sew and then criticized every stitch the teen made to 'encourage precision' — the teen never returned but the lesson stuck.
She has a talent for remembering prices and will correct store clerks publicly if rung up incorrectly; uses this skill as a minor power play.
As a girl, she sneaked into a movie with a friend and got caught; she retells the story with pride, as an example of youthful audacity.
She keeps two outdated driver's licenses pinned among recipes as a reminder of the years she could still drive anywhere — losing that freedom would be the last straw.
Dorothy occasionally slips in compliments that are folded inside insults — a manipulative habit that keeps people off-balance.
She collects small stories of human failure and tells them as cautionary tales, often at the expense of empathy.
Her house smells of old soap, fried food, and the paper of secondhand books; visitors notice this as a signature presence.
She once confronted a hospital administrator in person and demanded an accounting of charges; the administrator later called her 'unusually persuasive' in private.
Dorothy keeps an old radio that picks up distant AM stations; at night she listens to talk radio and calls in once every few months to complain about taxes under a fake name.
If she suspects a grandchild is getting 'soft' she gives them a small, intentionally cryptic test (a chore or request) and judges their response for grit.
